choices.text: Reabsorption rate of glucose equals the filtration rate of glucose
Excretion rate of glucose increases with increasing plasma glucose concentrations
Renal vein glucose concentration equals the renal artery glucose concentration

questions.text: At plasma concentrations of glucose higher than occur at transport maximum (Tm), the
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

At concentrations greater than at the transport maximum (Tm) for glucose, the carriers are saturated so that the reabsorption rate no longer matches the filtration rate. The difference is excreted in the urine. As the plasma glucose concentration increases, the excretion of glucose increases. When it is greater than the Tm, the renal vein glucose concentration will be less than the renal artery concentration because some glucose is being excreted in urine and therefore is not returned to the blood. The clearance of glucose is zero at concentrations lower than at Tm (or lower than threshold) when all of the filtered glucose is reabsorbed, but is greater than zero at concentrations greater than Tm.

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent boy is being treated with the macrolide antibiotic erythromycin complains of nausea, intestinal cramping, and diarrhoea. The side effects are the result of the antibiotic binding to receptors in the GI tract that recognize which gastrointestinal hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Motilin
Erythromycin group of drugs bind to motilin-like receptors in the GI tract. Motilin stimulates increased contractions by a direct action on smooth muscle and by activation of excitatory enteric nerves. This results in increased intestinal motility, abdominal cramping and diarrhoea.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with neurogenic orthostatic hypotension is experiencing significant symptoms despite lifestyle modifications. Which medication is often used as a first-line treatment to increase blood pressure and improve symptoms?

questions.text: Which of the following is a PARP inhibitor used in cancer therapy, particularly for BRCA-mutated tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Olaparib

Everolimus: This is an mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) inhibitor primarily used in various cancers, including renal cell carcinoma and neuroendocrine tumors, but it is not a PARP inhibitor.
Olaparib: This is a specific PARP inhibitor indicated for treating certain types of cancers, particularly breast and ovarian cancers that harbor BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations. It has shown effectiveness in improving progression-free survival in patients with these genetic alterations.
Ceritinib: This drug is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used primarily to treat non-small cell lung cancer with ALK (anaplastic lymphoma kinase) rearrangements, not a PARP inhibitor.
Atezolizumab: This is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that targets PD-L1 (programmed death-ligand 1) to enhance the immune response against tumors. While effective in various cancers, it does not belong to the PARP inhibitor class.

questions.text: Which measure of obesity can differentiate between fatty and muscular obesity?
questions.solution:

Explanation
Obesity Assessment:
–    Quetelet Index, BMI = Weight (kg)/ Height (m 2)
–     Ponderal Index, BMI = Height (cm)/cube root of body weight (pounds)
•    Or, = Weight * 100/ Height3
–     Broca index, Ideal weight = Height (cm) – 100 
–     Corpulence index = Actual weight/ Ideal weight (Normal <= 1.2)
–     Lorentz formula, Ideal Weight =  Ht (cm) – 100 – Ht (cm) – 150
                                                             2 (women) or 4 (men)
•    Skin fold thickness

–    Herpenden skin callipers are used for estimating
–    Measured at 4 sites – Mid triceps (single best site), mid biceps, subscapular, suprailiac

questions.text: An 89-year-old man present with sensorineural hearing loss after stapedectomy. Correlate the given Axial CT and choose the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cochlear Otosclerosis

Ref:Read the text below

Sol
•    Axial CT in the patient with sensorineural hearing loss after stapedectomy shows extensive lucency surrounding the cochlea (arrows), consistent with cochlear otosclerosis.
•    Cochlear otosclerosis is defined as otosclerosis located in the otic capsule involving the cochlear endosteum and causing sensorineural hearing loss or mixed type hearing loss. It has been clearly shown that when otosclerosis is sufficiently severe to involve the cochlear endosteum, it usually fixes the stapes as well.
•    Patients with otosclerosis who have progressed to profound hearing loss derive significant benefit from cochlear implants; however, an increased risk of cochlear ossification and facial nerve stimulation has to be taken in account during preoperative counseling.

questions.text: Neonatal facial palsy is most likely caused by which of the following?

Ref:Read the text below
Sol
•    Congenital (present at birth) facial paralysis is uncommon and, when present, may cause multiple problems for the newborn, such as difficulty with nursing and incomplete eye closure. 
•    If the paralysis does not resolve, it may affect the child's future speech, expressions of emotion, and mastication. 
•    This article discusses the etiologies, evaluation, diagnostic testing, and treatment options for this disorder. 
•    Congenital facial paralysis is classified as traumatic or developmental, unilateral or bilateral, and complete or incomplete (paresis).

questions.text: 35 year old female suddenly complained of an attack of bleeding from her right ear (otorrhagia).An ENT specialist packed the ear and after removal of the pack found an aural polyp. The patient also complained of pulsatile tinnitus in the right ear of 2 years duration and a change in her voice of 2 months duration. On laryngeal examination there was right vocal fold paralysis, the vocal fold was found in the abduction position. No lymph node enlargement was found in the neck.All of the following are true statements except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Its rate of growth is very fast.
Ref:Read the text below
Sol

  • Right glomus jugulare tumor (bleeding from the ear, pulsatile tinnitus and neurological manifestations of the jugular foramen syndrome)
  • The tumor is often seen in the middle age (40–50 years).
  • Females are affected five times more.
  • It is a benign, nonencapsulated but extremely vascular neoplasm. 
  • Its rate of growth is very slow and several years may pass before there is any change from the initial symptoms.Tumour is locally invasive.

•    Glomus jugulare. They arise from the dome of jugular bulb, invade the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, causing neurological signs of IXth to XIIth cranial nerve involvement.They may compress jugular vein or invade its lumen.

•    Glomus tympanicum. They arise from the promontory of the middle ear and cause aural symptoms, sometimes with facial paralysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is absolute contraindication to the use thrombolytic agent the setting of an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ischemic stroke in the last 1 month.

2013 Task Force ACC/AHA guidelines for Thrombolysis in STEMI

Absolute contraindications for fibrinolytic use in STEMI include the following: 
•    Prior intracranial hemorrhage (ICH)
•    Known structural cerebral vascular lesion
•    Known malignant intracranial neoplasm
•    Ischemic stroke within 3 months
•    Suspected aortic dissection
•    Active bleeding or bleeding diathesis (excluding menses)
•    Significant closed head trauma or facial trauma within 3 months
•    Intracranial or intraspinal surgery within 2 months
•    Severe uncontrolled hypertension (unresponsive to emergency therapy)
•    For streptokinase, prior treatment within the previous 6 months

Relative contraindications for fibrinolytic use in STEMI include the following: 
•    History of chronic, severe, poorly controlled hypertension
•    Significant hypertension on presentation (systolic blood pressure >180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure >110 mm Hg
•    Traumatic or prolonged (>10 minutes) cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) or major surgery less than 3 weeks previously
•    History of prior ischemic stroke not within the last 3 months
•    Dementia
•    Recent (within 2-4 weeks) internal bleeding
•    Non-compressible vascular punctures
•    Pregnancy
•    Active peptic ulcer
•    Current use of an anticoagulant (e.g. Warfarin) that has produced an elevated international normalized ratio (INR) higher than 1.7 or a prothrombin time (PT) longer than 15 seconds

questions.text: 54-year-old male presents with 1 month of diarrhea. He states that he has 8–10 loose bowel movements a day. He has lost 4 kg during this time. Vital signs and physical examination are normal. Serum laboratory studies are normal. A 24-hour stool collection reveals 500 g of stool with stool osmolarity of 260. Based on these findings, what is the most likely cause of this patient’s diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 
This patient has a stool osmolality gap of less than 50, suggesting a secretory rather than an osmotic cause for diarrhea. Secretory causes of diarrhea include toxin-mediated diarrhea (cholera, enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli) and intestinal peptide–mediated diarrhea in which the major pathophysiology is a luminal or circulating secretagogue. The distinction between secretory diarrhea and osmotic diarrhea aids in forming a differential diagnosis. Secretory diarrhea will not decrease substantially during a fast and has a low osmolality gap. Osmotic diarrhea will generally decrease during a fast and has a high (>150) osmolality gap. Other causes leads to osmotic diarrhea.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with thick greenish nipple discharge from both breasts. There is no palpable breast lump, although both nipples are slightly retracted. The patient does not take any medication. Mammogram and ultrasound do not show any evidence of cancer. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mammary duct ectasia and periductal mastitis have a diverse clinical spectrum. The aetiology is unclear but involves the accumulation of secretions in the duct and inflammation of the surrounding tissues leading to inflammation, sometimes secondary infection, a thick nipple discharge and nipple retraction. Secondary infections can sometimes follow and  inflammatory masses in the peri-areola region can form abscesses and mammary fistulae between the ducts and the skin at the areola margin.

Duct ectasia is a nonspecific dilatation of the major subareolar ducts with occasional involvement of the smaller ducts, unrelated to fibrocystic change. 

Microscopically, the dilated ducts contain foamy macrophages mixed with lipid material, cholesterol clefts and eosinophilic debris. The material within the ducts often calcifies. Infiltration of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes occurs in the periductal tissue. With time, fibrosis increases in amount. Thus terms, such as plasma cell mastitis, obliterative mastitis and comedomastitis, were used. 

Treatment: Hadfield Operation

The inflammatory phase is treated with antibiotics, for example metranidazole or surgery of the major ducts, including local incision and drainage of abscess or major duct excisions for more chronic cases.

•    Cellulitis of the soft tissue involving the floor of the mouth and neck. 
•    Involves all three compartments of the floor of the mouth- sublingual, submental, and submandibular.
•    The infection is rapidly progressive, leading to potential airway obstruction.

•    Usually polymicrobial, involving both aerobes, and anaerobes. 
•    “Woody" or brawny cellulitis involving the submandibular space.
•    Rapidly spreading cellulitis without lymphatic involvement and causes rapid air way compression.
•    Treatment involves securing the airway and drainage.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of right-hand anesthesia that developed after an argument with her brother. She is in good spirits and seems unconcerned about her problem. There is no history of physical trauma. The neurologic examination is negative except for reduced sensitivity to pain in a glove-like distribution over the right hand. Her entire family is in attendance and is expressing great concern and attentiveness. She ignores her brother and seems unaware of the chronic jealousy and rivalry described by her family. The patient’s enjoyment of the attention and concern of her family is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Secondary gain
Conversion disorder is characterized by symptoms or deficits of the voluntary motor or sensory functions that cannot be explained by neurological or other medical conditions. These symptoms are precipitated by psychological conflicts. 
The patient’s lack of anxiety and apparent lack of awareness of the conflicts with her brother are classic findings in conversion disorder and they are described as called “primary gains.” This term refers to the use of physical symptoms to express a conflict, emotion, or desire without allowing it to enter the patient’s consciousness. 
The patient’s enjoyment of her family’s attention is a form of “secondary gain.” Secondary gains, being experienced as pleasurable, reinforce the symptoms. There is no such thing as “tertiary gain.” 
“Suppression” is a mature defense mechanism and consists of a voluntary decision to put a disturbing thought temporarily out of the conscious mind.

Examination shows that his pulse is rapid and pupils are dilated. He states that he "feels just awful" and that he has had these symptoms for about 24 hours. questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clonidine

The man is suffering from opiate withdrawal. The drug on the list to treat the withdrawal is clonidine.

questions.text: MATCH THE FOLLOWING:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

Cervical ectopic is diagnosed by Paalmann criteria, ovarian ectopic by Speigelberg, Primary abdominal ectopic by Studdiford, PCOS by Rotterdam and AEPCOS, Bartholin gland cancer by HONAN criteria.

choices.text: Do vaginal delivery of the first baby and internal podalic version of the second baby
Do vaginal delivery of the first baby and caesarean for the second baby.

questions.text: A 26 years old G2P1A0L1 has twin pregnancy with the following presentation at 39 weeks. She is in latent labour with adequate uterine contractions and her pelvis is adequate. What should be the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Do caesarean section

This is breech-transverse presentation. Whenever the first baby is in non-cephalic presentation, we must do caesarean section to avoid interlocking twin syndrome.

questions.text: A 32 years old multiparous patient has following fetal presentation. Identify the given presentation and position:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mento posterior

This is a picture of face presentation and the mentum of the fetus is towards the sacrum of the mother and hence it is mento-posterior position. Mentoposterior position cannot be delivered vaginally and hence caesarean section is necessary.

questions.text: WHO guidelines for second stage of labour includes:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hot compresses to perineum 

In order to avoid perineal tears in the second stage; perineal support, perineal massage, hot fomentation, prevention of premature extension and avoiding routine episiotomy are the guidelines by WHO.

questions.text:
For diagnosis of placenta accreta which investigations are used?
1. Usg
2. MRI
3. XRAY
4. PET scan
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1&2 


USG doppler is an investigation of choice. MRI is more accurate but it is rarely required. XRAY and PET are contraindicated.

questions.text: Pregnant woman presented with spotting per vaginum. Her BP was 110/70 mm Hg, Usg image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Complete mole

This is a picture of a snow storm appearance. It is due to presence of multiple, fluid filled, grape like vesicles in uterus. It is a case of complete molar pregnancy.

questions.text:
Instruments used for Caesarean section: 
A. Green Armitage
B. Allis Forceps
C. Cusco Speculum
D. Doyen Retractor
E. Karman Cannula
F. Shirodkar needle
G. Scalpel
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A,B,D,G

Green Armitage is used to hold the uterine incision, Allis forceps are used to hold the rectus sheath and uterine incision, Doyen retractor is used to retract the anterior abdominal wall, scalpel is used to take an incision.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a complication of multifetal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Post term pregnancy

There is an overdistension in multifetal pregnancy which triggers the labour in preterm state. Post term pregnancy is not seen with multifetal pregnancy.

choices.text: Rh negative patient with ICT positive status
Rh negative patient with Rh positive neonate with DCT positive status
Rh negative patient with Rh negative neonate with DCT negative status
Rh negative patient with Rh positive neonate with DCT negative status

questions.text: Which one of the following is an indication of injection Anti-D?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rh negative patient with Rh positive neonate with DCT negative status

ICT is the test to detect ANTI-D in mother’s blood and DCT is the test to detect ANTI-D in fetal blood. 

If mother is already isoimmunised, there is no need of Inj. Anti-D. If the baby is Rh negative then there is no risk of isoimmunisation.

questions.text: Which one of the following parameters of ultrasonography is best for evaluation of fetal growth in a patient who is primigravida with 31 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Abdominal circumference

Abdominal circumference is the most sensitive parameter for evaluation of growth disorders like FGR and MACROSOMIA.

questions.text: A baby is delivered at term by FACE-TO-PUBIS delivery. Which one of the following types of pelvis is most likely associated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anthropoid

Face to Pubis delivery is also known as OP delivery. It is seen most commonly in anthropoid type of pelvis. Anthropoid pelvis is antero-posteriorly oval in shape with broader posterior segment and hence the baby engages in OP position and delivery in OP position.

choices.text: Inverted T shaped incision in past

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions can be subjected to trial of labour after caesarean section (TOLAC)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Polyhydramnios

Inverted T shaped incision is an upper segment incision. Post term pregnancy has macrosomia. Naegle’s pelvis is a contracted pelvis. In all these cases, VBAC is prohibited. Polyhydramnios is not a contraindication.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a cause of polyhydramnios?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Posterior urethral valve

Posterior urethral valve is a cause of oligohydramnios. It is responsible for Potter’s sequence in which there are skeletal defects and lung hypoplasia. USG shows keyhole sign.

questions.text: A 31 years old nulliparous patient has come to the gynae opd with symptom of something coming out per vaginum. On examination, the following was identified. What is the best treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Shirodkar sling surgery

Young nulliparous patient with uterine prolapse must be treated by Shirodkar sling surgery. In this surgery, the isthmus of the uterus is tied to the sacral promontory by a tape.

questions.text:
Steps of taking PAP smear
A. Vaginal retractor
B. Scrape Transformational zone
C. Making thin smear
D. Fixation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A B, C, D

Ayre’s spatula is used and the fixative is 955 alcohol.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs is not useful in a case of PCOS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Danazol is never used in PCOS. It is an androgenic drug with anti-estrogenic property. It is used in fibroids and endometriosis.

questions.text: HPV inhibits Rb gene acting through which of these?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

E7

E6 inhibits p53 and E7 inhibits pRb. L1 and L2 are capsid proteins. L1 is used for making vaccine.

questions.text: A 17 years old girl has come to the gynae OPD with history of primary amenorrhoea. She has normal secondary sexual characters with positive progesterone challenge test. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

PCOS
ASHERMAN will give negative PCT and EPCT. PCOS will give positive PCT since there is only a deficiency of progesterone. SAVAGE will give positive EPCT but negative PCT. SWYER will not have normal secondary sexual characters.

choices.text: Menopause at the age of 31 years

questions.text: Which one of the following is not an indication of hormone replacement therapy (EPRT)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

MRKH syndrome

MRKH syndrome is 46XX with normal ovaries and secondary sexual characters but with absence of uterus, cervix and vagina. There is no need of HRT in this case.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs is responsible for reducing the endometrial thickness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ormeloxifene

Ormeloxifene is a SERM with anti-estrogenic property on the endometrium. It is used as a contraceptive since it causes endometrial atrophy.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

URGENCY INCONTINENCE—BURCH COLPOSUSPENSION

In VVF, we do Martius flap surgery in which labia majora- fibrofatty tissue is interposed between bladder and vagina. Ureterovaginal fistula is treated by ureteric reimplantation surgery called as Boari flap surgery. Vault prolapse is dealt by an abdominal surgery called sacro-colpopexy in which we tie the apex of vagina with sacral promontory by mersilene tape. Urgency incontinence would not require any surgery.

questions.text: Which one of the following is included in the definition of PID?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Endometritis

PID is an upper genital tract infection and inflammation. It includes uterus, tubes and ovaries.

questions.text: In which case of vaginal discharge, there is no WBC infiltration seen in the discharge?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gardnerella vaginalis

Gardnerella vaginalis causes bacterial vaginosis. There is no inflammation in this infection. There are no signs of inflammation like itching, redness or WBC in discharge.

choices.text: Granulosa cells produce oestradiol under control of FSH
Theca cells produce androstenedione under control of LH
Granulosa cells produce progesterone due to LH
Theca cells produce progesterone due to FSH

questions.text: Which one of the following is not true regarding steroidogenesis in ovary?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Theca cells produce progesterone due to FSH

Theca cells are under the control of LH. These cells produce androgens which are then taken up by granulosa cells to produce estrogen and progesterone.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not seen in unicornuate uterus with rudimentary horn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Transverse lie

Unicornuate uterus can never have transverse lie since there is no space in the transverse direction. There is a chance of breech presentation, recurrent abortions and preterm labours. Rudimentary horn can lead to ectopic and endometriosis.

questions.text: At what stage of lung development, is surfactant seen in the type II pneumocytes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Canalicular

 
Normal fetal alveolar development occurs in the following stages:

●Embryonic period – At approximately 26 days gestation, the embryonic stage begins with the first appearance of the fetal lung, which appears as a protrusion of the foregut. The initial branching of the lung occurs at 33 days gestation forming the prospective main bronchi, which begin to extend into the mesenchyme. Further branching forms the segmental bronchi as the lung enters the next stage of development.

●Pseudoglandular stage – In the pseudoglandular stage (5th to 16th weeks of gestation), 15 to 20 generations of airway branching occur starting from the main segmental bronchi and ending as terminal bronchioles. At the end of the pseudoglandular stage, the airways are surrounded by a loosely packed mesenchyme, which includes a few blood vessels, and is lined by glycogen-rich and morphologically undifferentiated epithelial cells with a columnar to cuboidal shape. In general, epithelial differentiation is centrifugal, so the proximal airways are lined with the most differentiated cells, with progressively less differentiation in the more distal tubules.

●Canalicular stage – During the canalicular stage (16th to 25th weeks of gestation), the transition from previable to a potential viable lung occurs as the respiratory bronchioles and alveolar ducts of the gas exchange region of the lung are formed. The surrounding mesenchyme becomes more vascular and condenses around the airways. The closer vascular proximity ultimately results in fusion of the capillary and epithelial basement membranes. After 20 weeks gestation, cuboidal epithelial cells begin to differentiate into alveolar type II cells with formation of cytoplasmic lamellar bodies. The presence of lamellar bodies indicates the production of surfactant, which is produced from glycogen and stored in the lamellar bodies.

●Saccular stage – At the beginning of the saccular stage (approximately 24 weeks gestation), there is potential for viability because gas exchange is possible due to the presence of large and primitive forms of the future alveoli. In this stage, formation of alveoli (ie, alveolarization) occurs by the outgrowth of septae that subdivide terminal saccules into anatomic alveoli, where air exchange occurs. The number of alveoli in each lung increases from zero at 32 weeks gestation to between 50 and 150 million alveoli in term infants and 300 million in adults. Alveolar growth continues for at least two years after birth at term.

questions.text: A 29 week, 600gm baby is born in the labour room. The baby has moderate respiratory distress, with a silverman score 6. What is the next appropriate step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Nelson’s 21st edition 
•    Early use of nCPAP for stabilization of at risk preterm infants beginning early (in the delivery room) reduces the need for mechanical ventilation.
•    Assisted ventilation and surfactant are indicated for infants with RDS who cannot keep oxygen saturation >90% while breathing 40–70% oxygen and receiving nCPAP.
•    Early nCPAP is beneficial compared to intubation and prophylactic surfactant, because avoidance of mechanical ventilation is associated with a reduction in death and/or BPD. Infants at the extremes of GA (<24 wk) and those that were not exposed to antenatal corticosteroids may still benefit from intubation and surfactant prophylaxis

questions.text:
A Pakistani couple are referred for genetic counseling. They lost two children who both died in the first 2 years of life. They have one healthy girl, who is 3 years of age. The faulty gene has been identified and other members of their family have been tested.

What is the pattern of inheritance in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Autosomal recessive

questions.text: This boy has proximal muscle weakness, aged 6 years. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

DMD

questions.text: A 2 yr old child child is given a breakfast cereal containing cashew nuts. He suddenly has stridor and is struggling to breathe. There is no rash or wheeze and he remains conscious. He is brought to your resuscitation unit tired and unable to cough.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text:
A 3-year-old otherwise healthy girl develops irritability, headache, and myalgias shortly after waking up one morning. Later that day she develops fever to 40°C ( 1 04°F) and becomes lethargic. In the emergency department she is found to have meningismus, as well as purpuric lesions on her trunk and extremities with scattered petechiae. She has hypotension that requires fluid resuscitation and vasopressor support. She is intubated to protect her airway. Blood cultures obtained are positive and are growing gram-negative diplococci.
Empiric antibiotics should include:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The correct answer is ''A:' This child has meningitis with purpura fulminans caused by Neisseria meningitidis. Onset can be mild, but progression to fulminant disease can be rapid, with a high rate of mortality even with rapid empiric antibiotic treatment.

choices.text: Obtain an electrocardiogram (ECG) to look for occult arrhythmia.
Measure glucose, lactic acid, and ammonia, and start IV fluids with at least 10 % dextrose concentration
Start the infant on ampicillin and gentamicin for presumed sepsis.
Await the results of an echocardiogram before making further management decisions.
Obtain plasma amino acids and urine organic acids to look for metabolic disease.

questions.text:
A 7 -day-old infant girl is brought into the emergency department unconscious. Her parents accompany her and report a history of an uneventful pregnancy and delivery at 39 weeks' gestational age, with no unusual postnatal events, and discharge on day of life 2. The parents report that the infant's behavior was normal during the first 3 days at home, but for the past 2 days she has not wanted to feed as much. They were not terribly concerned until about an hour before admission when she became difficult and then impossible to awaken. Emergency department personnel report that they already have plans to evaluate the infant for a cardiac lesion and infectious disease.
What are the most important immediate steps in evaluation and treatment of this critically ill infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


The correct answer is "B:' When a child presents with a critical illness, it is vitally important to determine acid-base status, ammonia level, and blood glucose, as these will have immediate management implications and results will be quickly available.

questions.text: Maple syrup urine disease is a disorder of branched-chain amino acids.  Which of the following amino acids is not considered a branched-chain amino acid that would be elevated in a patient with maple syrup urine disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The correct answer is "D:' Histadine is not a branched-chain amino acid.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old postmenarchal girl comes to the clinic with concerns of early morning clumsiness after several episodes of breaking dishes and glasses at breakfast. She describes an uncontrollable brief jerk of her shoulders and arms that causes them to fling out, resulting in the broken dishes. On further questioning, she admits to having had a few episodes where she woke up having wet the bed at night and with blood in her mouth from biting his tongue. Her exam is normal. You suspect seizures and order an MRI, which is normal, and an EEG, which shows a 4- to 6-Hz generalized polyspike-and-wave pattern.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The correct answer is ''A:' Myoclonic seizures are brief, involuntary (usually single) , asymmetric jerks typically involving the arms. They characteristically occur in the morning hours, leading to dropped toothbrushes, curling irons (and burns! ) , and broken dishes. Children are often accused of being clumsy until they have their first generalized tonic-clonic seizure. A minority of children also have absence seizures. Benign rolandic epilepsy (option "B") is a form of autosomal dominant epilepsy that is typically "benign" because the majority of children only have a handful of seizures over their lifetime. It typically manifests around 8 years of age and remits by age 14. The typical seizure occurs at night and consists of one-sided facial tingling followed by twitching, drooling, and difficulty speaking. The child is fully aware of what is going on. The seizure can spread to involve the arm or even go on to a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Treatment is not needed unless seizures are frequent or disruptive, in which case oxcarbazepine or carbamazepine is preferred. The seizures described in this patient are all generalized (myoclonic and presumed generalized tonic-clonic) and would not be part of complex partial or absence epilepsy.

questions.text:
During another busy day in clinic, a 5-month-old boy is referred to you for evaluation of atypical movements. The infant was born at term and had been healthy with normal development. A few weeks ago, he started having attacks during which his body crunches up repeatedly then stops. The dusters frequently occur right after he wakes up. The mother shows you a video on her phone. During the episode, the infant's head thrusts forward while his entire body repeatedly flexes together and then extends.
What is the most likely cause of these events?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


The correct answer is "A:' Infantile spasms (also known as West syndrome) begin in the first year of life with peak onset between 4 and 6 months of age.

questions.text: 2 Images: Patient with lung cancer. Image 1 shows a right hilar mass. What complication has occurred at the time of image 2 which was acquired 4 months after image 1?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Phrenic nerve palsy
Image 2 shows the right hilar mass has enlarged. The right hemidiaphragm is raised indicating phrenic nerve palsy due to compression or erosion by the mass.
There is no visible pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

questions.text: Alcoholic found unconscious. What does the image show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Extradural haematoma


Learning points
This image shows lentiform increased density material indicating acute blood in the extra-axial space (not in the brain). These are the typical appearances of an extradural haematoma.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman known for a chronic bone disorder with markedly elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. What is the most likely chronic bone disease shown on her lateral skull radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paget disease


Pagets
This skull radiograph demonstrates:
thickened, disorganised trabeculae with extensive poorly defined sclerotic patches giving the typical "cotton wool appearance"
widening of the diploic space: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved
relatively well-defined lytic lesion involving mainly the outer calvarial table of the occipital bone which may represent an osteoporosis circumscripta
Tam o' Shanter sign: with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat
platybasia and basilar invagination can not be properly appreciated on this skull radiograph
The clinical history of a chronic bone disorder, with marked elevation of the serum alkaline phosphatase and radiographic features are highly suggestive of Paget disease.

questions.text: 40 year old male patient with mucopurulent cough underwent CT examination, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bronchiectasis
Chest x-rays are usually abnormal but are inadequate in the diagnosis or quantification of bronchiectasis. Tram-track opacities are seen in cylindrical bronchiectasis, and air-fluid levels may be seen in cystic bronchiectasis. 
CT and HRCT especially excel at demonstrating the airways and is able to a greater or lesser degree to distinguish some of the various underlying causes.
A number of features are helpful in diagnosing bronchiectasis:
1. tram-track sign
2. Signet ring sign
3. String of pearls sign
4. Bunch of grapes sign

questions.text: 30 year old with BMI 18 with progressive difficulty in swallowing in both solids and liquids for 8 months. Barium swallow is shown to you.  What other investigation should be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

UGI endoscopy + Manometry
This is classic picture of achalasia cardia
Manometry is indicated for confirmation of diagnosis.
Achalasia: barium swallow study may be used to confirm oesophageal dilatation, in addition to assessing for mucosal abnormalities. 

Findings include:
bird beak sign or rat tail sign
oesophageal dilatation
tram track appearance: central longitudinal lucency bounded by barium on both sides
incomplete lower oesophageal sphincter relaxation that is not coordinated with oesophageal contraction
pooling or stasis of barium in the oesophagus when the oesophagus has become atonic or non-contractile (a late feature in the disease)
uncoordinated, non-propulsive, tertiary contractions
